wikipedia_page.main: William Fraser McDonell VC (17 December 1829 – 31 July 1894) was a British civil servant, judge and a recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces. He is one of only five civilians to have been awarded the VC.

response: * William Fraser McDonell, Bengal Civil Service, Arrah, India, 30 July 1857 aged 27

link_mentions.page: List of English Victoria Cross recipients
response: |William Fraser McDonell || Civilian || 1857 || Indian Mutiny || Arrah
* Mr. William Fraser McDonell, Bengal Civil Service, winning the V.C. near Arrah, 30 July 1857 (National Army Museum)
thumb|alt=William Fraser McDonell VC|William Fraser McDonell VC|200px

During the retreat from Arrah, Ross Mangles and William Fraser McDonell (civilian magistrates, and personal friends of Wake, who had volunteered to serve with Dunbar's expedition) earned the Victoria Cross—Mangles, despite being wounded, carried a wounded soldier from the 37th Regiment of Foot for several miles while under fire, and McDonnell exposed himself to heavy fire to cut a rope that was preventing a boat from making its escape, saving the lives of 35 soldiers.

link_mentions.page: List of people educated at Haileybury and Imperial Service College
response: ** William Fraser McDonell, VC (attended East India College Haileybury) - A Civilian recipient.Frederick Charles Danvers, (1894), Memorials of Old Haileybury College, page 607, (A. Constable and Company)
